entry.content:
Custom Z80 Computer Home

Overview

The chassis is a cheap metal project box that you can find all over Amazon or eBay. I liked it because the color reminded me of an Altair 8800. I 3D printed some parts to help hold the PSU I chose and the disk drives. The PSU is something I pulled out of a computer years ago, either a Dell or Compaq. The backplane is sandwiched in between two 3D printed pieces. Bolts come up through the bottom of the chassis through the  guide rails for the PCBs to hold the entire assembly together. I'm not happy with this design. Eventually I want to get a larger backplane so I can install more cards. Right now, I can't fit everything at the same time.

The backplane is just a 40 row strip board with pin headers soldered on it.

This board just controls the clock and reset signal for the computer. I do not have a reset circuit when the computer is turned on, so the computer needs to be manually reset. You can halt the computer with a switch and manually step the processor with a button on the front.

The schematic is not complete.

entry.content:
Custom Z80 Computer Home

Overview

Currently this board is very simple because only the IDE part is implemented. Eventually, a floppy controller will be added to this board. 
The hard disk is connected directly to the Z80's bus. I'm considering re-making this board and adding bus transceivers for both the IDE disk and the FDD controller. So far, I've only found 1 model of hard disk that works with this setup, and I'm assuming its because there's no bus transceiver. Only 8 bits of the 16 bit data bus on the hard disk is used. The other top 8 are pulled to ground. The only chip on the board is a 3 to 8 demux for address decoding.

Software

To be added.

entry.content:
Custom Z80 Computer Home

Overview

I wanted to try out wire wrap, but I didn't have enough space on the back of the board, or any wire wrap sockets. So, I soldered pin headers on either side of the ICs and wire wrapped on the top of the board. Its not the nicest looking wire wrap, but I'm happy with how it came out. It's also easy than doing point to point soldering in my opinion. 

I don't have an application yet, but eventually I'd like to write a clock program to write to my VFD Board I designed. I was going to read the time from an i2C clock chip by bit banging with the PIO.

entry.title: UART Board
entry.summary: Custom Z80 Computer Home This is the second board I made in 2017. I've made some changes to it in 2020 when I started to add more boards to the system. Before, the address decoding was done with a few different 74LS logic chips. I…
entry.content:
Custom Z80 Computer Home

Overview

This is the second board I made in 2017. I've made some changes to it in 2020 when I started to add more boards to the system. Before, the address decoding was done with a few different 74LS logic chips. I replaced it with a single 74LS128 3 to 8 demux. I was also having issues with the 16c550 not resetting correctly, so I tied the reset signal into the computers reset circuit. It should have been like this from the start. I needed to invert the signal, so I used a 74LS00 NAND since this was already on the board from the old address decoding.
The crystal for the UART is 1.843200MHZ. We write 12 to the divisor latch. Then, it is divided internally by 16. This gives us 9600 baud. You can see this in uart.s in the SetupUART routine.

I still have issues with this chip not resetting sometimes, so more investigation is needed.

Custom Z80 Computer Home

Overview

This was the first board I built for the computer. I'm not happy with how it looks, but it works. I improved my construction techniques in the later boards.
This board has the z80 CPU, Flash, SRAM, an OR gate for memory address decoding, a 3 to 8 demux for IO address decoding, and a latch that disables the ROM.

The only change I needed to make to this board was adding the latch and IO decoding.

entry.content:
Digital Home

This was the first Digital computer I acquired. The system has a 100MB and a 200MB hard disk installed. Currently, I leave them disconnected because I don't want to damage them, or damage the install of OpenVMS 6.2 since I have no idea how to use OpenVMS.

The reason I have the front panel removed is so I can easily plug in my RaSCSI to the SCSI bus. I don't have the correct cable to connect to the external SCSI connector on the back.

I've tested a few different operating systems including OpenVMS 7.2, Ultrix 4.5, and NetBSD. NetBSD was interesting since it's a new OS. The SSH keys took about 45 minutes to generate. I don't think I'm going to take the effort to learn OpenVMS, but I'd like to get an OS with a GUI running on it.
